articles.description: Sebastian Vettel's departure from Ferrari appeared to be Daniel Ricciardo's pathway back to the big time. So why didn't he take it? As ever in Formula One, things are not quite that simple.
articles.content:
The news Sebastian Vettel would not be renewing his Ferrari deal beyond 2020 appeared to be manna from heaven for Daniel Ricciardo, who seemed the most logical alternative to the outgoing four-time world champion.
A proven race winner, popular and with Itali… [+6163 chars]

articles.author: Marc Churches
articles.title: Peter V'landys hits out at 'ludicrous' referees following Fair Work Commission dispute - Wide World of Sports
articles.description: Follows their dispute with Fair Work Commission
articles.content:
ARLC chairman Peter V'landys has hit back at the referees' union after it lodged a dispute with the Fair Work Commission over the NRL's decision to reduce the game to one referee.
The NRL confirmed yesterday that the pocket referee would be gone for the rest… [+2179 chars]

articles.description: Tune into our new show Fox League Live on Channel 502 Monday to Friday at 6.30pm and on Saturday at 3pm and Sunday at 5pm.
articles.content:
The NRL has taken the most calculated risk of the Peter Vlandys era by scrapping the two referee system and reverting to one whistleblower.

articles.title: McLaren F1 welcomes Aussie ace Daniel Ricciardo - WhichCar
articles.description: F1's 2020 silly season has just ramped up, as Daniel Ricciardo jumps ship from Renault
articles.content:
Australian F1 driver Daniel Ricciardo will jump ship from Renault to McLaren, in the wake of the confirmation of Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel's departure from Ferrari.
He has signed a multi-year deal that kicks off in 2021.

articles.author: Shane Wright
articles.title: Australians told to prepare for even worse as job numbers crash - Sydney Morning Herald
articles.description: The jobs market is set to deteriorate even more despite a record drop in the number of people with a job as concern grows about home construction sector.
articles.content:
The Morrison government's $130 billion JobKeeper program prevented the headline jobless rate being even worse as millions of people, barred from working, are still being paid through the wage subsidy scheme.
